title: Port of Newcastle wins Glencore price wars
text:
Down to the ACCC now

Glencore’s withdrawal from the contest over the port’s declaration leaves the law reform ball right in Sims’ court and we can expect to hear a whole lot more from the ACCC chairman and the coal producers on the need for a new monopolies test.

“If the Port of Newcastle service and others like it cannot be captured by the current test, the regulatory framework must be changed,” Sims told a conference in Canberra this month.

“A monopolist that controls this type of bottleneck infrastructure, operating without any regulation, has a clear incentive to maximise profits and usually by raising prices, even if this means reduced volumes or the use of their service.

“It is bad for the economy when bottleneck infrastructure, at the end of a crucial value chain, is in the hands of a company with unfettered market power. A monopolist in that situation will always use its power – the question is only by how much and how often.

“How is it that Australia, much more so than other countries we compare ourselves to, allows this?"

The new dilemma for the ACCC is that the latest ACT decision has the potential to establish a new and unwelcome precedent in creating a formula that releases the Port of Newcastle to increase its fees beyond the range already set by Sims & Co.

The ACT redrafted the fees set last year by the ACCC because it found fault with the mechanism of arbitration. The ACCC used what it believed was a standard process that set a maximum allowed revenue by establishing a replacement value of the port as the starting point for a process that established the final value of the regulated asset base (RAB).

Advertisement

The replacement value was put at $2.169 billion and from that the ACCC deducted the value of a slate of capital works at the port that had been funded by the customers. As a result, the RAB was trimmed to $1.257 billion, and the ACCC ended up trimming the port fees whose hike started this circular, three-cornered contest back in 2015.

The ACT’s re-arbitration of the port’s regulated fee base found, for a host of technical reasons, that the ACCC had erred in discounting the customer-funded component of the port’s capital works. It accepted instead that Port of Newcastle’s lengthy arguments, with included the concept that “bygones should be bygones” when it comes to historic capital costs.

A very bad precedcent

Looked at through the ACCC lens, the ACT decision allows fees to be set on capital works that were paid for by customers. In this case, 42 per cent of the capital spent on sustaining the shipping channel was raised under the user pays regime enforced by the NSW government.

Allowing that investment to be included in the RAB means that the customers effectively pay twice for the asset, just as it allows the Port of Newcastle’s new owners the opportunity to earn monopoly rents from investments that their business did not pay for.

“I find the decision disappointing in that companies that have paid for assets to be built now have those folded into an asset base and they have to pay for them all over again,” Sims told The Australian Financial Review on Wednesday.

“That seems to me both unfair and to set a very bad precedent. Why would any company contribute to user funding in the future if they end up getting charged twice?”

Like so much in this elongated process, that simple clarity doesn’t quite capture the complexity of the particular situation at the Port of Newcastle.

Advertisement

According to the evidence presented by the Port of Newcastle, Glencore wasn’t one of the users that actually contributed to the five channel projects that accounted for the ACCC’s deduction. So, the port operator argued, given the ACCC ruling only covered Glencore’s fees, why should it benefit from the capital provided by other users?

Well, that is a question that may yet require further test. Who might best run that test is another matter entirely. It is far from clear whether Glencore has the appetite for a further legal challenge or whether the ACCC would have standing enough to force a judicial review of the ACT ruling.

Three-cornered bunfight

The immediate effect of ACT’s re-arbitration of a set of findings the ACCC delivered in July last year is that the Port of Newcastle is free to dramatically increase the navigation service fee it charges Glencore to a peak much higher than the one that started this three-cornered bunfight way back in 2015.

Then, just months after Hastings Funds Management and China Merchants paid a staggering $1.75 billion for the Port of Newcastle, the new operators moved to hike fees for accessing their shipping channel and wharves by 40-60 per cent, depending on the size of the vessel its customers were using.

The navigation fee – which is by far the most material – rose to 78.86 cents a gross tonne in 2015 and then stepped up to 75.53 cents in 2018.

In between that first rise and the second, Glencore – the port’s biggest user – trooped off to the National Competition Council seeking declaration of the port under Part IIIA of the Competition and Consumer Act.

When the NCC rejected Glencore’s application, the miner headed off to the ACT, where it was more successful. That success resulted in declaration and the delivery of arbitration powers to the ACCC. Further discussions between port operator and customer failed to produce an agreement and the ACCC was called in.

Advertisement

The ACCC trimmed the contentious navigation fee by 19.5 per cent to just 60.75 cents a tonne. That fee was backdated to July 8, 2016, and the ACCC established a five-year review provision that would see a review of the RAB based on capital invested over the regulated period that did not come from customers.

The rest should have been history. But it wasn’t and, after nearly five years of see-sawing fortunes, the Port of Newcastle management and its owners have emerged with higher regulated fees than they had set themselves and freed from the complications of declaration.

Not surprisingly, given that total victory appears to be at hand, Port of Newcastle management put out a pretty chipper statement in the wake of the ACT’s generosity.

The operator welcomed a decision that offered incentive for a service provider to invest in a timely and efficient way to maintain and improve their infrastructure.

“We have long said that port pricing should remain subject to an appropriate and efficient commercial relationship between the port and its customers,” Port of Newcastle chief executive Craig Carmody said.

After wishing for the end of a “period of unnecessary uncertainty”, Carmody said he was “looking to sitting down with all our customers to discuss our services and pricing”.
description: The operator of the world's biggest coal port signals a new round of price negotiations after securing back-to-back victories in its war with it major customer and the ACCC.
